Award.AwardTitle: Computational Methods and Data Assimilation in Nonlinear Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer simulation is a critical ingredient of modern science. Simulations that depend on the solution of differential equations are subject to small modeling, truncation, and ﬂoating point arithmetic errors. A relatively new set of algorithms, called set-oriented methods, have been developed for the analysis of structures in computational dynamics. We propose to build a foundation for analyzing the possible effect of the errors on these techniques and others used in computational dynamics. The second major focus of this project is the interpretation of data collected from experimental systems and nature when only a partial mathematical model is available. We will
investigate a range of techniques which, depending on the completeness of the available model, can be used to attempt to reconstruct the model and dynamical behavior of the process, with potential to predict or control the process. Complex deterministic time series from physical, and biological/medical settings that are produced by network dynamics will be particular applications.

The project focuses on two major areas: the development of new approaches to study computer simulation validity, and the interpretation of experimental data from nonlinear processes. Computer simulation is a critical ingredient of modern science. Simulations are subject to errors both in modeling and computation. The proposal builds a foundation for analyzing the possible effect of the errors on set-oriented simulation results, for physically relevant models. The second major focus of this project is the interpretation of data collected from experimental systems and nature when only a partial mathematical model is available. We will investigate a range of techniques which can be used to attempt to reconstruct the model and dynamical behavior, with potential to predict or control the process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this grant, we made significant progress in developing computational methods for the problem of finding dynamical structure from multivariate time series data, and developed new model-based, sequential-in-time methods to assimilate data in nonlinear problems, including dynamical networks. In particular, we proposed a manifold learning algorithm combining multivariate delay coordinate reconstruction methods pioneered by the PI Sauer and others with the diffusion maps paradigm, now called Diffusion-Mapped Delay Coordinates (DMDC). Also, we developed a new strategy for adaptive data assimilation algorithms, based on the ensemble Kalman filter, for state estimation and control of chaotic systems and complex networks. Data assimilation is heavily used in numerical weather prediction, and is gradually becoming inportant in the interpretation of scientific experiments and other uses of complex data.

Further accomplishments during the grant were at the forefront of exploring data-driven, nonlinear approaches to system identification such as filtering, prediction, noise reduction, and tracking. In the past we have developed black-box algorithms, but in this grant project we are finding ways to exploit existing data assimilation methodology in cases where partial model information is available.  Another aspect of our research is attempting to remodel diffusion maps theory to move it from globally-defined kernels to locally-defined kernels. This will be pivotal in multiscale problems where the density of information varies greatly in the phase space. Broader impacts of the grant consisted in transferring the research results to educational projects with students, and training of a graduate student in these areas.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2016
Modified by: Timothy D Sauer
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In this grant, we made significant progress in developing computational methods for the problem of finding dynamical structure from multivariate time series data, and developed new model-based, sequential-in-time methods to assimilate data in nonlinear problems, including dynamical networks. In particular, we proposed a manifold learning algorithm combining multivariate delay coordinate reconstruction methods pioneered by the PI Sauer and others with the diffusion maps paradigm, now called Diffusion-Mapped Delay Coordinates (DMDC). Also, we developed a new strategy for adaptive data assimilation algorithms, based on the ensemble Kalman filter, for state estimation and control of chaotic systems and complex networks. Data assimilation is heavily used in numerical weather prediction, and is gradually becoming inportant in the interpretation of scientific experiments and other uses of complex data. Further accomplishments during the grant were at the forefront of exploring data-driven, nonlinear approaches to system identification such as filtering, prediction, noise reduction, and tracking. In the past we have developed black-box algorithms, but in this grant project we are finding ways to exploit existing data assimilation methodology in cases where partial model information is available. Another aspect of our research is attempting to remodel diffusion maps theory to move it from globally-defined kernels to locally-defined kernels. This will be pivotal in multiscale problems where the density of information varies greatly in the phase space. Broader impacts of the grant consisted in transferring the research results to educational projects with students, and training of a graduate student in these areas.
